data.text: Contents
Policy Statement

The Trust Board recognises that the provision of healthcare and the activities associated with the treatment and care of patients and service users, employment of staff, maintenance of premises and management of finances, by their nature, incur risks.
The Trust is committed to implementing the principles of good governance, defined as:
The system by which the organisation is directed and controlled to achieve its objectives and meet the necessary standards of accountability, probity and openness.

The Trust recognises that the principles of governance must be supported by an effective risk management framework, designed to ensure safe care and treatment to patients, the safety of staff, patients and visitors and deliver continuous improvement.

The Trust is committed to having a risk management culture that underpins and supports the business of the Trust and intends to demonstrate an ongoing commitment to improving the management of risk throughout the organisation.

The Trust recognises that strategic and business risks cannot always be avoided, but, where relevant, can be embraced and explored in order to grow business and services, and take opportunities in relation to the risk. Considered risk taking is encouraged, together with experimentation and innovation within authorised limits. The priority is to reduce those risks that impact on safety, and reduce our financial, operational, relationship and reputational risks.
Introduction
This document sets out the Risk Management Policy of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (The Trust). It provides guidance on the policy, processes and procedures for risk management.

Risk management is both a statutory requirement and an indispensable element of good management at the Trust. It is a fundamental part of the total approach to quality, corporate and clinical governance, and is essential to the Trust's ability to discharge its functions as a partner in the local health and social care system, as a provider of health services to the public and an employer of significant numbers of staff.
The Trust is committed to providing high quality, cost-efficient, sustainable and effective healthcare services for its population and meeting its strategic objectives.

To achieve this, the Trust recognises and appreciates that it will need to take risks in a measured, considered and appropriate way. Good risk management is a tool that supports and empowers staff in this regard by enabling them to identify, assess
and control risks in a way that is visible, consistent and makes best use of resources.

The Trust is committed to ensuring that the risk management framework minimises threats as far as reasonably possible, though not necessarily eliminating treats, and maximises opportunities This will support the Trust to achieve its objectives and safeguarding against harm to patients, staff and visitors, minimising financial loss and reputational damage.

The Trust encourages an open culture that requires all Trust employees, contractors and third parties working within the trust to operate within the systems and structures outlined in the strategy, escalating any risk where required.
Risks at the Trust will be managed in an open, honest and transparent way within a culture that supports and encourages this approach.
The Trust Board and all staff will have awareness and understanding of the risks that affect patients, visitors, and staff.

The Trust's risk management system will be transparent, consistent, replicable, robust, auditable and meet the reasonable requirements of the Trust's regulators and auditors taking into account costs and available resources.
Purpose and Scope of the policy
The purpose of this policy is to:
Promote organisational success and help the Trust to achieve its objectives;
Have organisational oversight of key risks;
Empower staff to manage risks effectively;
Promote and support proactive risk management;
Help create a culture that recognises uncertainty and supports considered, measured and appropriate risk taking and effective risk management;
Support new ways of working and innovation;
Provide clear guidance to staff;
Have a consistent, visible and repeatable approach to risk management;
Support good governance and provide internal controls;
Evidence the importance of risk management to the Trust.

This policy applies to all Trust employees regardless of position held, as well as consultants, vendors, contractors, and/or any other parties who have a business relationship with the Trust. It will be brought to the attention of all employees and form part of the induction process for new staff.
This policy applies to all risks which include but are not limited to:
Clinical risks;
Communications risks;
Environmental risks
Financial risks;
Fraud risks;
Governance risks;
Information risks;
IT risks;
Operational risks;
Quality and safety risks;
Regulatory and compliance risks;
Reputational risks;
Strategic risks.
Security
Definitions
Definition of terms used throughout this document

table_items.text: is ‘the mitigated' risk remaining after all reasonable controls have been applied (as much as possible has been carried out to control the risk) to associated hazards that have been identified, quantified, analysed, communicated to the appropriate level of management and accepted after proper evaluation'. Sometimes referred to as the acceptable or tolerable risk

The Board Assurance Framework (BAF) provides the Trust with a simple but comprehensive method for the effective and focused management of the principal risks to meeting its objectives. It also provides a structure for the evidence to support the Chief Executive's Annual Governance Statement.

The chance of something happening to a patient during NHS care that could lead to unintended or unexpected harm, loss or damage. This is a broad definition that may range from dissatisfaction, to undergoing the wrong operation, or suffering permanent disability or death.
is the level of harm that has, or may be suffered and is measured at the Trust on a scale of 1 to 5, 1 being negligible or no harm and 5 being severe harm.
are arrangements and systems that are intended to minimise the likelihood or severity of a risk. An effective control will always reduce
the probability of a risk occurring. If this is not the case, then the control is ineffective and needs to be reconsidered. Controls are intended to improve resilience

The permanent or currently unavoidable clinical risk that is associated with a particular clinical investigation or treatment. It is the risk from undergoing a particular procedure in ideal conditions and performed by competent staff using the most up-to-date research, equipment and techniques. It can be considered permanent or currently unavoidable when used for the purpose of risk assessment. Sometimes referred to as inherent risk

An Issue is an event or set of events that have materialised or will definitely materialise. An issue is different to a risk; a risk is something that may happen where as an issue is something that has happened, was not planned but requires management action. When risks become issues, they should be taken off the register and be managed by divisions as business as usual. However, risk owners may find more comfort in monitoring some of their serious issues on the register. In this case, the issue will remain on the register.
Is measured by the frequency of exposure to the hazard or the probability of an event occurring on a scale of 1 to 5.
A risk that can adversely affect the achievement of the Trust's strategic objectives. These risks are identified, assessed and monitored by the Board Assurance Framework.

Is the risk remaining with the current controls in place i.e. the risk remaining after the controls put in place to mitigate the initial risk are fully effective. Sometimes referred to as residual risk

Is the likelihood (probability) that an event with adverse consequences or impact (hazards) will occur in a specific time period, or as a result of a specific situation. This event may cause harm to patients, visitors, staff, property, or have an impact on the Trust reputation, corporate objectives, stakeholders or assets. Risks differ from their hazard in that the former is the calculated probability of the event occurring whilst the consequences or impact measure the effect of the risk being realised as a hazard. Put simply, hazards represent risks that have been realised.

The amount of risk exposure, or potential adverse impact from an event, that the Trust is willing to accept/retain. Once the risk appetite threshold has been breached, risk management treatments and business controls are implemented to bring the exposure level back within the accepted range. The risk appetite may vary according to risk type.

Is the process by which risks are prioritised and then categorised through the application of a 5 by 5 calculation to produce a composite score out of a maximum of 25 (25 being the most severe). The risk assessment is based on the probability (likelihood) of a hazard occurring on a scale of 1 to

5, multiplied by its likely consequence or impact (severity) which is measured on a similar 1 to 5 scale. An account of the criteria for obtaining accurate measures of risk and severity of consequence or impact can be found in the Risk Management Procedure.

The organisational Risk Assurance Framework (RAF) is a part of the Trust risk management system and provides a mechanism for recording details of each risk within a database so that risk records can be analysed and facilitate effective oversight of risk management at all levels. The RAF is a register of risks which have been evaluated but not yet fully controlled or which the Trust accepts it must retain; these are therefore risks which may impact upon meeting Trust objectives. The RAF includes details of the nature of the risk, the severity, likelihood and overall rating, the service(s) which owns the risk, the controls currently in place, assurances including the forum where progress in mitigating the risk is monitored, and progress achieved. The Trust uses the Datix system to record the RAF which is also referred to as risk registers.

Is the systematic identification, assessment, treatment, monitoring and communication of risks. This process is followed by the application of current or planned resources to effectively control, monitor and minimise the overall likelihood (and in some instances, impact) of the identified risk

A document used as a risk management tool, acting as a repository for all risks identified and includes additional information about each risk, for example; current controls, organisational objective affected by the risk and planned actions. It is a dynamic document that needs to be updated regularly.
The whole network of systems established in the Trust to provide reasonable assurance that organisational objectives will be achieved.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Trust Board

The Trust Board and its committees will provide oversight and scrutiny of the most serious organisational risks and hold people to account in this regard. In addition, the Trust's Non-executive directors will play a lead role in ensuring effective oversight and scrutiny of the Trust's risk management policies, procedures and systems.
The Trust Board will:
Ratify the risk management strategy, and subsequent revisions;
Provide oversight, review and scrutiny of the Trust's highest level risks;
Receive regular risk reports of extreme operational risks;
Hold risk owners to account for their risks;
Review the Board Assurance Framework;
Approve the Trust's Risk Appetite;
Horizon scan and communicate findings for action.
Trust Board sub committees Trust Board sub committees will:
Provide scrutiny, review and oversight of key risks (appropriate to the remit of each Committee);
Receive risk reports;
Horizon scan and communicate findings for action;
Hold risk owners to account for their risks.
Audit Committee
The Audit Committee will:
Provide independent assurance to the Trust Board on the effectiveness of the risk management process within the Trust and compliance with risk management arrangements;
Approve the risk management policy and strategy;
Receive independent reports on the effectiveness of risk management in the Trust;
Challenge the way in which risk is managed where there is uncertainty or concerns over the effectiveness of risk management arrangements;
Formally assess on an annual basis the overall effectiveness of the risk management processes in the Trust and report to the Trust Board;
Review risk management arrangements for the purposes of the Annual Report and the Annual Governance Statement;
Horizon scan and communicate findings for action;
Hold risk owners to account for their risks.
Quality Governance Group

The purpose of the Quality Governance Group is to monitor the management of all areas of risk that may impact on the Trust's achievement of its strategic objectives and act as a gatekeeper for the escalation of risks to the Executive Team for consideration as corporate risks, where the escalation criteria as described in the Risk Management Strategy are met.
Trust Executive Management Team
The Executive Management team will:
Review and provide guidance on the risk management policies and procedures;
Agree and approve resources for risk management across the Trust;
Provide operational oversight and scrutiny of high level risks across the Trust;
Ensure staff are effectively managing risks and that the Trust has an effective system of risk management in place;
Ensure staff are acting in accordance with risk management policies;
Have oversight and responsibility for operational risk management issues faced by the organisation;

Prepare a complete, accurate and reliable report on risk management for the purposes of the Annual Governance Statement to ensure it is fair and representative of the organisation's risk management arrangements;
Provide feedback on the risk management processes and policies supporting this strategy to the Risk and Compliance Team;
Ensure directors provide risk reports to the Trust Board and its subcommittees as appropriate;
Chief Executive Officer

The Chief Executive, as the Accountable Officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has in place sound systems of internal control, including risk management, which meet all statutory requirements and adhere to the risk guidance issued by the Department of Health.
The Chief Executive provides leadership and strategic direction to risk management processes. This responsibility includes resource allocation relating to the significant risks of the Trust.
The Chief Executive Officer will;
Ensure that the Trust's Principal Objectives are agreed;
Internal Audit Plans review the effectiveness of the system of internal control;
Prepare and sign an annual Governance Statement for inclusion in the Trust Annual Report;
Ensure that an Annual Quality Account is prepared.
The Chief Executive has delegated lead responsibility for risk management to the Chief Nursing and Quality Officer who is accountable to the Board for the Trust's management of risk.

Non-Executive Directors are accountable to the Chair and are the custodians of corporate governance. They are responsible for ensuring that the trust manages risk effectively and that the controls and systems of risk management are robust and defensible. NED champions are identified for a number of specific areas and they play a key role in ensuring the identification and management of risks in these areas including infection control; safeguarding; Freedom to Speak up; Maternity safety; learning from deaths; end of life; and doctors remediation.

Executive Directors - are responsible for reporting on controls and assurances of the highest risks to the Trust objectives through the Board Assurance Framework (BAF). Each Director is accountable for risk management leadership including the implementation of, and compliance with current Trust policies, and for ensuring sufficient resources have been allocated to undertake effective risk management. They are responsible for ensuring corporate and strategic risk registers are reviewed on a monthly basis. Leading by example, they are fundamental in establishing and sustaining an environment of openness on risk management within the Trust.
Chief Nursing and Quality Officer

The Chief Nursing and Quality Officer is the designated Clinical Governance lead for the Trust. They are accountable for ensuring that risk management systems are in place to identify, assess risks and that there are processes in place for effective planning, organisation, control, monitoring and review of preventative and protective measures. They are responsible for fulfilling the statutory duty of quality improvement and the overall implementation of Clinical Governance across the Trust. They report monthly to the Trust Board on governance, risk and compliance and also oversee the proposed escalation of risks in accordance with the Trust's escalation process. The Chief Nursing and Quality officer has delegated specific responsibilities for managing risks associated with safeguarding adults and children, patient experience and patient safety to the site Directors of Nursing.

Chief Medical Officer - is responsible for implementing systems of internal control to manage the key risks emanating from clinical activity throughout the Trust, employment of doctors and their practice, training, supervision and revalidation and the actions being taken to control them. They are accountable for advising the Board of the risks and effectiveness of controls and provide written advice to the Accounting Officer on the content of the Annual Governance Statement in regards to the management of these risks.

Chief Financial Officer – is responsible for implementing financial systems of internal control including the reporting of fraud to NHS Protect. They are responsible for informing the Board of the key financial risks within the Trust, the actions being taken to control them, and provide written advice to the Accounting Officer on the content of the Annual Governance Statement regarding financial risk.

Chief Information Officer (CIO) – is responsible for risks associated with information systems and contracts. The CIO is also the Trust Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO) with ownership and champion of the Trust's Information Governance Policy. The CIO provides written advice on information risk to the Accounting Officer for the Annual Governance Statement.
Chief Commercial Officer (CCO) – is responsible for risks associated with commercial strategy

Chief Estates and Facilities Officer – Is the lead for health and safety and is responsible for ensuring systems are in place for the identification, review and management of health and safety risks to employees, patients and those affected by the Trust activities, including risks associated with clinical equipment and medical devices. They provide a report to the Board on the management of health and safety risks and are responsible for risks associated with the trust environmental infrastructure.

Site Managing Directors - are accountable to the Chief Executive for the maintenance of effective systems of internal control within their areas of responsibility. They are responsible for ensuring that risk action plans from serious incidents and risks are implemented in a timely manner as agreed.
Director of Governance

The Director of Governance is accountable to the Chief Nursing Officer for the strategic leadership of risk management. They are responsible for promoting a safety culture throughout the Trust to deliver all elements of the clinical governance and risk agenda and to lead risk management across the group and ensuring that strategies, policies and risk management frameworks are robust.
Associate Director of Risk and Compliance

The Associate Director of Risk and Compliance is accountable to the Director of Governance and is responsible for professional leadership and overseeing and managing the Trust processes for governance including risk management and the board assurance framework. They are responsible for the day to day management of the Board Assurance Framework and Corporate Risk Register.

Care Group Directors - are responsible for ensuring the agreed risk management procedures, systems and processes are implemented, embedded and effective in the areas for which they are accountable. They are responsible for ensuring clinical risks, health and safety risks, emergency planning and business continuity risks, relevant project and operational risks are identified and managed. The have a responsibility to correctly identify risk, the scoring of risk and compliance with Trust controls. Directors delegate operational management decision-making and responsibility for the day-to-day management of health and safety and risk to their respective Deputy Directors and Associate Directors.
Divisional Directors/Heads of Departments/Ward Managers/Matrons
Divisional Directors, Heads of department and other Managers will:
Manage risk within their area of responsibility as appropriate and report on these risks to the Risk Owner;
Support the Risk Owner in the management of their risks and in writing any risk reports required;
Work within this policy;
Ensure the teams and staff under their control manage risk effectively and follow this policy;
Ensure they and their teams receive risk management training;

Work with the Risk and Compliance Team and help ensure timely and smooth production of risk reports, the Corporate Risk Register and the Board Assurance Framework - and the smooth operation of the risk management system;
Ensure appropriate and timely risk assessments for the division;
Highlight any problems or concerns with any risk with the Risk Owner.
Risk and Compliance Team
The Risk and Compliance Team will;
Provide central oversight of the risk management process and system in the Trust, including this policy;
Provide specialist advice on all risk;
Prepare risk reports for the Trust Board and its sub committees;
Ensure that the Board, directors and clinicians have the information they need to manage their identified risks;
Provide training for staff and Trust Board members in relation to risk management.
The Risk and Compliance Team is not accountable or responsible for the actual management of the risks; this sits with Risk Owners and Risk Leads.
Divisional Governance Leads/Facilitators
Directors may appoint Divisional Governance Leads who will;
Ensure that risks within their areas are recorded and reviewed appropriately and in a timely manner;
Escalate new risks for approval in accordance with the Trust's risk escalation process;
Support directors in managing the risk management process within their directorates and assist with risk reporting;
Support the Risk and Compliance Team in delivering and embedding the Trust's approach to risk management;
Help drive effective risks management within divisions;
Help support staff to implement the Trust's risk management policies and procedures;
Assist staff within their directorates to co-ordinate risk reporting;
Maintain a central folder within each division containing the meeting notes/minutes from risk management meetings within the division.
All Staff
All Trust staff, self-employed consultants, contractors, office holders and Trust Board and committee members have a duty to;
Comply with the risk management/health and safety arrangements appropriate to the work task being undertaken.
Report to their line manager any deficiencies that could impact upon the health, safety and welfare of individuals (patients, staff, contractors, etc.).
Complete and submit an incident report form in the event of a reportable incident (refer to the Trust's Incident Policy).
Escalate by the quickest means possible incidents where serious harm has occurred or the potential for serious harm exists/existed (refer to the Trust's Incident Policy).
Follow the Speak Up policy if they feel unable to raised issues via alternative routes
Participate as directed by line management in any training deemed necessary to effectively manage risk.
Comply with the Trust's key policies for risk management and any professional guidelines and standards set by the relevant professional bodies and associations.
Use protective equipment as provided for the task to be undertaken if risk assessment determines its necessity.
Not intentionally or recklessly interfere with or prejudice equipment that has been provided for the safety of them or others.
Risk management process
6.1 There are five steps to the risk management process which form a continuous cycle (refer to appendix 1 for the risk management process).
Risk registers and risk oversight

Accountability through monitoring, reporting and communication are key considerations throughout the risk management process for both internal and external stakeholders. This ensures those who are responsible for implementing risk management and those with a vested interest, understand the decision making process and why particular actions are required. The Risk Reporting Structure can be seen in Appendix 3

Specialty/Divisional Risk Registers - Each specialty / division, for example Surgery, shall have a Risk Register which contains all of the risks identified in the specialty or division. Nominated risk leads within the service are responsible for managing the risks and for ensuring any risks are escalated as appropriate.

Care Group Risk Registers - Risks can be considered for escalation to be included in the care group risk register. The risks from the divisional or care group Risk Registers with a current risk score of 15 and above should be considered for inclusion on the Corporate Risk Register as per the risk escalation process set out in Appendix 4.
Corporate Risk Register

7.4.1 The Corporate Risk Register (CRR) is the corporate high level operational risk register used as a tool for managing the most serious organisational risks and monitoring actions and plans against them. Used correctly it demonstrates that an effective risk management approach is in operation within the Trust.

7.4.2 The Corporate Risk Register (‘CRR') is made up of the extreme operational risks that have been agreed for inclusion in the CRR. Each risk is linked to one of the Trust's strategic risks and strategic objectives. Each risk will be owned by an Executive Lead and is reported to the relevant Board Sub-committee for scrutiny. Risks with a current score of 15 or higher, or those considered to have a significant impact should they be realised, are considered for inclusion on the CRR.

7.4.3 Risks can be identified for inclusion on the CRR via a number of sources including but not limited to; Trust Board, Board Sub-committees, Executive Team or the Quality Governance Group. Risks considered for inclusion should be sent to the Risk and Compliance Team using the Candidate Risk Form (see appendix 5) and will be presented to the Trust Management Executive Group (TMEX) for consideration.

7.4.4 Risks agreed for inclusion on the CRR will be presented to the next relevant Board Sub-committee for scrutiny. Risks not agreed for inclusion on the CRR will be de- escalated back to the care group / division for local management.

7.4.5 Risks may be de-escalated from the CRR when; the risk has reduced to a sufficient rating that this can be considered for local management at care group / divisional level (usually risks rated less than 12); when the target risk rating has been achieved; or when the risk has been closed (risk no longer exists). Risks proposed for de-escalation from the CRR or closure will be presented to TMEX for approval before being removed from the CRR.
Board Assurance Framework

7.5.1  The Board Assurance Framework (BAF) sets out the strategic objectives, identifies risks in relation to each strategic objective along with the controls in place and assurances available on their operation. The BAF can be used to drive the board agenda. The strategic risks will be determined by the Trust Board and will be kept separate on a strategic risk register. The strategic risk register will form part of the BAF. Trust Board subcommittees will decide which of their corporate risks may be presented to the Trust Board as part of the BAF for oversight but these would usually be the extreme risks rated  or more.
Risk Oversight

7.6.1 Specialty or divisional risk registers will be reviewed by the nominated risk lead on a quarterly basis or as otherwise required. Risks with a current risk score of 15 and above will be reviewed monthly and may be considered for inclusion in the care group risk registers.

7.6.2 Care Group risk registers will be reviewed by the nominated lead on a monthly basis or as otherwise required. Risks with a current risk score of 15 and above will be considered for inclusion in the CRR.

7.6.3 A summary of the risk register will be exception reported to the divisional / care group governance meetings monthly, including any newly identified risks for approval, risks with an increased score, risks for closure and any emerging risks. All risks with a score of 8 and above are presented to the divisional governance meetings on a quarterly basis

7.6.4 An exception summary report will be presented from each care group on a quarterly basis. Each division and corporate service will present a summary update on their risk register on a quarterly basis to include risks with a score of 15- 25, new risks, risks with an increased score, retired risks and any emerging risks. In addition to this, divisions or care groups should escalate any emerging risks, new risks or risks with an increased score of 15 or more on a monthly basis. The Quality Governance Group will agree on the escalation of risks to the Trust Management Executive (TMEX) for consideration of inclusion on the CRR.

7.6.5 The CRR will be presented to the Executive Management Team on a monthly basis or as otherwise agreed by the Executive Management Team for operational scrutiny, review and oversight. The Executive Management Team may re-grade, add, amend or remove risks at its absolute discretion.
7.6.6 Risks on the CRR will also be presented to the appropriate Board subcommittee for scrutiny, review and oversight at each committee meeting or as otherwise agreed by the committee.
7.6.7 The CRR and BAF will be presented to the Audit Committee for oversight.

7.6.8 Strategic risks will be presented to the relevant Board Sub-committee and the whole strategic risk register will be presented to the Trust Board as part of the BAF at each Trust Board meeting or as otherwise agreed by the Trust Board. Board sub committees may nominate any of their risks to be presented to the Trust Board as part of the BAF for scrutiny, review and oversight although this would usually be the extreme operational risks. This ensures that the Trust Board can concentrate its focus and attention on the most serious risks.

7.6.9 There will be a small number of risks on the specialty risk registers which are purely operational and may reach the threshold for escalation to divisions but do not reach the threshold for the CRR or BAF. These risks may, on a case by case basis and at the discretion of the Risk Owner, be presented to the Trust Management Executive Team for scrutiny, review and oversight. In most instances it will be clear that a risk is purely operational whereas at times it will be a matter of judgment.
7.6.10 Board members have the responsibility to horizon scan and formally communicate matters in the appropriate forum relating to their areas of accountability.
Risk appetite and risk capacity

The Risk Appetite is the amount of risk that the Trust is willing to accept. Risks throughout the organisation should be managed within the Trust's risk appetite, or where this is exceeded, action is taken to reduce the risk. The Trust Board decides and sets the Risk Appetite levels.

The Risk Capacity is the maximum amount of risk that the Trust can bear. The Trust Board and the Trust Management Executive Team will continue to consider the organisation's capacity to bear risks and ensure it stays aligned with the Trust's objectives and the operating environment to ensure risk is managed in a controlled way.
It is important that the Risk Appetite does not exceed the Trust's capacity to effectively manage its risks and the Trust's ability to meet the system control total.

On an annual basis the Trust will publish its risk appetite statement in respect of each of the principal risks that together contribute to the Board Assurance Framework. The risk appetite is reported in the risk and control framework statement within the Annual Governance Statement.
The most up to date Trust Risk Appetite statement is found on the Trust intranet and website.
Training and education

The Trust aims to manage risks effectively and create a culture that recognises uncertainty and supports considered, measured and appropriate risk taking. To achieve this all staff will be provided with appropriate training. Refer to the training needs analysis in Appendix 9
It is the responsibility of all staff and their line managers to ensure they are available for and receive risk management training.
New members of staff joining the Trust will receive training in the fundamentals and principles of risk management as part of the Trust corporate induction.

The Trust Board will receive training at least once every two years, to ensure that the requirement to understand and discharge duties in relation to risk management at Board level is reviewed and refreshed, thereby maintaining compliance with nationally agreed regulations. Risk awareness sessions will be included as part of the board's development programme.

All staff are able to request additional risk management training if they feel it will help support them in their role or are interested in developing their skills further. All requests should be made to the  Risk and Compliance Team.
Monitoring compliance and effectiveness of implementation
The Trust will ensure effectiveness of the arrangements in this policy through an annual review of the policy and whenever there are changes to the regulatory guidance around risk management.

The Trust will seek assurance that risk management and related systems are sound, by commissioning an annual internal audit on the effectiveness of the system of internal control which includes a review of risk management arrangements.
The Terms of reference of the Board and sub-committees will be reviewed on an annual basis to ensure that responsibilities, in relation to risk management, are discharged appropriately.
The annual governance statement provides assurance of the level at which the Trust's system of internal control is managing organisational risks.
Approval, communication, and review

Prior to approval, this policy will be consulted upon by the individuals and groups set out in the consultation schedule on page 2 of this document. Upon successful consultation, the policy will be approved by the Audit Committee which is the specialist committee with the authority to approve The Trust's policies and guidelines relating to the Trust's system of internal control. The policy will be presented to the Audit Committee for ratification.
This policy will be reviewed every two years by the Risk and Compliance team and any changes (except changes to the appendices) will be approved and disseminated as set out in this policy.
Equality impact assessment

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. This policy has been created and written in accordance with the provisions of the Equality Act 2010 (‘EA 2010'). In addition, it supports the achievement of the aims of the EA 2010 and the Public Sector Equality Duty contained therein. Refer to Appendix 10 for the assessment.

Horizon Scanning

2.1.1 Risks are continually changing, either due to changes within or outside the Trust. The Trust needs to keep on top of these changes to make sure that it is prepared. It is important that the Trust Board continually  looks into the future to anticipate potential changes on the horizon allowing the Trust as much time as possible to plan and respond to these changes; this is often know as horizon scanning.

2.1.2 Horizon scanning focusses on identifying, evaluating and managing changes in the risk environment, preferably before they manifest as a risk or become a threat to the Trust. The Trust should consider on-going risks to services.

2.1.3 Additionally, horizon scanning can identify positive areas for the Trust to develop its business and services, taking opportunities where these arise. The Trust will work collaboratively with partner organisations and statutory bodies to horizon scan and be attentive and responsive to change.

2.1.4 The outputs from horizon scanning should be reviewed and used in the development of the Trust's strategic priorities, policy objectives and development. The scope of horizon scanning covers, but is not limited to:
Legislation
Government white papers
News
Government consultations
Research and survey outcomes
Socio-economic trends
Trends in public attitude towards health
International developments
NHSE/I publications
Local demographics
External meetings
Stakeholders views
Risk Assessments
2.1.5 All staff have the responsibility to bring to the attention of their managers, potential issues identified in their areas which may impact on the Trust delivering on its objectives.
Sources of Risk

2.2.1 Staff should initially consider what their main areas of work are and how these relate to their local objectives, and the objectives of the Trust. Every work activity that has a significant hazard should be assessed for risk. Identification using a systematic approach is critical, because a potential risk not identified at this stage will be excluded from further analysis. See Appendix  for sources of risk identification. The risk identification template in Appendix  can be used to determine how the Trust is likely to be affected by any hazard and its associated risks. The Trust Health and Safety policies should be referred to regarding the process for health and safety assessments required on an annual basis to identify health and safety related risks.
2.2.2 Key questions staff should always address are:
What could possibly go wrong; and at what point during the activity?
How could it happen and why?
What could be the effect?
Who could be affected?
Risk assessment and initial risk rating

The risk assessment stage involves the analysis of individual risks to identify the consequences and likelihood of the risk being realised. A single method of assessment adopted from the National Patient Safety Agency is used for all risks and is detailed at Appendix 6.

The key to understanding the true meaning of a risk is ensuring that the risk has a clear description and the risk to achieving the objective is identified and clearly described. The risk should be given a risk title to make it easy to quickly identify the risk and described in terms of the cause, effect and impact of the risk. The risk should be written in plain English and in a way that a lay member of the public would easily understand.

For example: If the trust fails to implement [X] procedure there is an increased risk that safe processes will not be followed. This may result in patient harm, poor patient outcomes and reputational damage.

All wards, departments, Corporate Directorates, Divisions and Care Groups are responsible for identifying all risks associated with the service provided (clinical and non-clinical), assessment and entry onto the risk assurance framework.

The initial risk assessment can be documented by direct entry onto the Datix System for those with access or by using the Trust Risk Assessment Template included as Appendix 8 or available on the Intranet.

Each risk assessor, upon identification of a risk, will complete all electronic fields on Datix (or the entire hard copy template) to ensure every aspect of the risk and its control is addressed. This shall include what the risk is, where it is, who may be harmed, how it is controlled, what further action is required and how assurance will be provided that the risk is being managed.
If a paper version of the Risk Assessment has been used, the assessment must be sent to the nominated individual within the division for entry onto the electronic system.

Upon receipt of a risk assessment, the risk will be discussed with the relevant manager to ensure the risk is appropriately described, the assessment is accurate and all required information as part of the assessment is completed. Once satisfied the risk is accurate and all the required information is recorded, they will ensure the risk is recorded on the Trust risk register reporting system (DCIQ).

If, during the completion of the risk assessment form, it becomes apparent that one or more of the hazards identified is a significantly higher risk than others, the risk should be entered onto the risk register separately, so as not to dilute high impact risks. Where a pattern or theme is apparent, then an overarching risk will be developed to take into account the wider context.
Each new risk added to the DCIQ system must be reviewed and approved by a member of the divisional triumvirate via the relevant governance meeting.
Risk rating is the combination of two factors:
The consequence or impact on a Trust objective if the risk occurs (‘Consequence'); and
The likelihood or probability of the risk occurring (‘Likelihood').
Both Consequence and Likelihood are measured on scales of 1-5 in accordance with the matrix in appendix 6:

The Trust risk assurance framework details three ratings to manage the risk. The first step in the process is to identify the initial risk rating which is the likelihood and impact of the risks before any controls are applied:
Initial risk rating – the (impact x likelihood) without any controls in place. The initial risk is sometimes referred to as the inherent risk;
Current risk rating – the (impact x likelihood) with controls in place at the time of assessment or review. The current risk is sometimes referred to as the residual risk;

Target risk rating – the (impact x likelihood) with all controls in place and all controls being fully implemented and working effectively. The target risk sometimes referred to as the mitigated, acceptable or tolerable risk.
Control identification and current risk rating
The current risk rating can be completed once the controls have been identified and the effectiveness of those controls has been assessed.

Controls are identified measures that are intended to minimise the likelihood or severity  of  a  risk.  An  effective  control  will  always  reduce  the probability  of  risk occurring. If this is not the case, then the control is ineffective and needs to be reconsidered. Controls are intended to improve resilience.
Controls that are currently in place should be identified and recorded. Any controls that are planned or yet to be embedded should be included in the ‘further controls' and ‘actions' section.
Controls may also be actions that are repeated, either regularly or in response to events, or they may be one-off actions or decisions. A control may be implemented to:
Terminate the risk;
Treat the risk;
Transfer risk; or
Tolerate the risk.
Trust controls fall into three main categories:

Prevention – these controls prevent a hazard or problem from occurring for example Policies, Procedures, Guidelines, Techniques, Processes, Training, Use of Equipment, Checklists, Computer Systems, Protective Clothing etc.
Detection – these controls provide an early warning of control failure; (for example Audit, Inspection, Monitoring, Incident Reporting, Smoke detectors, Complaints, Surveys, Tests etc): and

Contingency – these controls provide effective reaction in response to a significant control failure or overwhelming event and are designed to mitigate harm and improve resilience; (for example Evacuation Plan, Escalation Procedure, Continuity Plan, Backup Generator, Locum/Agency cover, Insurance etc).
It is important to note the following points when considering controls:
Resources including structured training, processes, procedures supervision or quality assurance can dramatically reduce the likelihood of a risk occurring;
Processes including press/communications management and contingency planning are effective at minimising the impact of most adverse events.

Where there are gaps in current controls or controls that are in development prior to maturity, then risk owners need to establish the most appropriate way forward and develop a risk action plan for implementation.

Ward, departmental, corporate and divisional managers must ensure specific, measurable, appropriate, realistic and timely (SMART) actions are taken to address identified gaps in control. There is an expectation that managers will ensure that action plans are delivered by the required date
Effectiveness of controls

4.9.1 The effectiveness of controls should be assessed through the process of obtaining assurance that the control is in place and is operating effectively. These assurances are obtained from a variety of sources, such as management reports, internal and external audit or other external sources such as reviews by regulators.
4.9.2 Assurances should be defined according to whether they are 1st, 2nd or 3rd line assurances.

st line assurance – Management; includes day to day risk management, staff training and compliance with policy, ward / specialty / divisional responsibility for risk and mitigation, strategy and plans.

nd line assurance – Internal assurance; includes training, support and tools for 1st line of defence provided by specialist teams, peer reviews, audits and inspections, sub-committee reports of st line of defence working effectively.
rd  line  assurance  –  External  assurance;  includes  internal  and  external audits, consultancy reviews, regulators and commissioners, external surveys i.e. GMC, CQC, PLACE etc.
4.9.3 Examples of controls are as follows

table_items.text: WHO audit carried out (2nd line assurance) and CQC inspection report of compliance to WHO standards (3rd line assurance)
Never events action plan in place
Evidence of never events action plan being implemented and on track (1st line assurance)

data.text: 4.9.4 The overall strength of the controls in place should be assessed. Strong controls will help to mitigate the risk further therefore assessing the strength will help to assess the level of risk and the priority to be given to maintaining or developing controls. There are four levels of effectiveness of controls;
Zero – the controls have no effect on controlling the risk
Weak – the controls have a low chance (1-60%) of successfully controlling the risk
Average – the controls have a moderate (61-79%) chance of successfully controlling the risk
Strong – the controls have a high (80%+) chance of successfully controlling the risk

4.9.5 Positive and negative assurance should be explained providing a clear description of what would be seen, known, understood if the controls were effective or not effective in mitigating the risk.

4.9.6 Any gaps in the assurances should be clearly identified and that appropriate actions are taken to identify any gaps in the assurance processes. There is an expectation that managers will ensure that actions to control assurance gaps are delivered within the same timescale as closing gaps in controls.
Target risk rating

4.10.1 The next stage in the process is to identify the target risk rating. This is the rating with all possible controls in place and all controls being fully implemented and working effectively. The target risk sometimes is referred to as the mitgated, acceptable  or  tolerable  risk.  The  Trust  risk  appetite  should  be  taken  into consideration when setting the target risk as this is the level of risk the Trust is prepared to accept in pursuit of its objectives before action is deemed necessary to reduce the risk.

4.10.2 The options for managing identified risks need to be assessed on the basis of cost and benefits derived. Options can be taken in combination or  separately. In general the cost of managing risks needs to be commensurate with the benefits obtained.  However,  decisions  should  take  account  of  the  need  to  carefully consider rare but severe risks, which may warrant risk reduction measures that are not justifiable on strictly economic grounds.
4.10.3 There are four options for responding to and managing identified risks and the decision on how to respond to the risks needs to take into account the level of risk.

table_items.text: The decision is taken to not proceed with the activity likely to generate the risks or removing the risk altogether. This is not usually an option in healthcare. Risk aversion can lead to missed opportunities and increase in other risk areas by failure to engage with appropriate decision making around risk management.
This option is about taking action to reduce the consequence and/or likelihood of a threat materialising.

The risk is transferred to another party in its entirety or partially. For example, service level agreements or jointly managed services. Where risks are transferred in whole, or in part, the organisation acquires a new risk in that the organisation to which the risk has been transferred may not managed the risk or their share in it appropriately.
Tolerate the risk and prepare a contingency plan

This option is about taking the chance that the threat will occur but having a contingency plan in place should it do so. This option is commonly used where the likelihood that a threat will materialise is low but the impact is high such as Emergency Preparedness. It is also often used when the likelihood that a risk will materialise is high and there is little that can be done to prevent the risk from materialising

data.text: Implement the plan - management of risk

Identification of Further Controls - If the risk cannot be avoided, transferred or accepted then the next stage is to identify whether any further controls are needed to reduce or modify the risk. Review the current controls in place to determine whether the effectiveness of the controls can be improved or whether there are additional controls that can be adopted. Consideration should be given to the cost of additional controls versus the additional impact these will have on reducing the risk.

Plan future actions - Where further controls are identified, the actions to implement these need to be clearly articulated using a SMART approach. Each action should have a lead assigned and be given a date by when the action is expected to be completed.
Implement the Plan and Review the Risk

5.3.1 Implement the actions – the actions taken to mitigate risk are a key aspect of a good risk management approach. Actions should link into the department / service improvement plans and strategies and should not be seen as standalone. Actions should not be entered onto a risk assessment and simply forgotten.

5.3.2 Identify the frequency for reviewing the risk – this should be based on the level of risk and the nature of the risk. In general terms, risks 8+ (High and Extreme risks) would generally be reviewed monthly whilst risks rated less than 8 could be reviewed quarterly. The date must be entered onto the DCIQ system.
Communicate, monitor and review the risk

When reviewing the risk, the current risk score should be reviewed in the same way as when the risk was initially identified. This is done by reviewing the effectiveness of the controls though the assessment of assurance obtained, reviewing and updating the actions taken to implement further controls and determining whether any additional controls can be identified and what action is required to implement these.
The review date should be updated to determine when the risk will next be updated
Risks must be escalated or de-escalated appropriately in accordance with this policy.
Review of Low and Moderate Risks – the following is a guide only

6.4.1 Risks with a current risk assessment of below  are reviewed, managed, monitored and owned within the wards or departments where they were initially identified. These risks are monitored locally by ward/ departmental managers. At any time that the ward or departmental manager feels that they are unable to manage the risk, they should seek advice with regards to escalation from their Divisional Lead.
6.4.2 In general terms, low and moderate risks should be reviewed at least quarterly
High Risks – the following is a guide only
6.5.1  Risks with a current risk rating of 8-12 should be reviewed quarterly. These risks will be escalated as appropriate as described below.
Extreme Risks – the following is a guide only
6.6.1  Risks with a current risk rating of 15 or more should be reviewed monthly. These risks will be escalated as appropriate as described below.
